title: Castrated
info:
Published in Diário de Notícias, Apr 14, 2013.

In portugal, part of the government's austerity package has been ruled unconstitutional. The Portuguese constitutional court has ruled that four of nine new austerity measures will have to be amended, neutering the proposed 2013 budget.

This only comes as a surprise to prime-minister Pedro Passos Coelho and finance minister Vitor Gaspar, for whom the constitution is a nuisance and the country's citizens mere statistics. They have done enough.

title: Clean exit
info: After three years of adjustment plans, the Troika (IMF, European Comission and ECB) leaves portugal. Some call it a "clean exit", a succesfull back on track without the need for new lines of credit. Others live in the real world.

title: Merkel's plan
info:
germany's Angela Merkel doesn't seem too keen on bailing out greece.

title: Discontent
info:
In Europe's poorer countries, the increasing austerity measures are fueling a latent desire for revolt. Soon, people may have very little to loose.

Published in Diário de Notícias, Oct 7, 2012.

title: Austerity and Health
info:
Published in Diário de Notícias, Jan 25, 2015.

People are reported dead while waiting too long for diagnosis and treatment in the ER of several public hospitals. Exhausted medical staff blames the successive budget cuts. It seems that for the portuguese government and the European Union, death makes economic sense.

title: Tax Evasion
info:
Published in Diário de Notícias, March 8, 2015.

Portuguese PM Pedro Passos Coelho is found to not have payed all due Social Security contributions between 1999 and 2004. When the media discovers the story, he quickly settles the debt. Even so, the standards his government imposes on the population, in the form of increasing taxes, steep fines for non compliance and welfare cuts, apparently are not so strictly applied to the top government official.

title: Magic
info:
By André Carrilho and Luís Lázaro, published in Diário de Notícias, March 17, 2013.

portugal's recession deepens, and the austerity measures imposed by the Troika just make it worse. Prime minister Pedro Passos Coelho and finance minister Vitor Gaspar are mere puppets of an ideologically motivated agenda that is completely detached from reality.

(note: in portuguese Coelho means rabbit, so I tend to draw our prime-minister with bunny ears)

title: Cuts in Public Spending
info:
Published in Diário de Notícias, Oct 13, 2013.

The portuguese government announces more cuts in public spending, including pensions, salaries and subsidies of state employees.

title: Riot control
info:
At the end of one of the greatest strikes in recent memory, with protests and demonstrations all over the EU, things get out of hand in Lisbon, portugal. After being provoked for a couple of hours by a group of agitators throwing rocks, the police decides to evacuate the parliament square. But the ensuing operation is not properly controlled, and people that were not involved in the provocation, including old women and teenagers, are brutally attacked and in some cases arrested. People going about their lives in nearby streets are even surprised by the wave of police force seemingly coming out of nowhere.

Published in Diário de Notícias, November 18, 2012.

title: The 99%
info: By André Carrilho and Luís Lázaro, for Diário de Notícias, November 6, 2011.

title: Angry Bird
info:
The EU is awarded the 2012 Nobel Peace Prize. But for how long will the founding ideals of peace and solidarity between nations survive, when democracy is sacrificed to sustain a common currency?

Published in Diário de Notícias, Oct 14, 2012.

title: Salazar (1924-1954)
info:
Cover illustration for a 5 part miniseries on the last 150 years in the History of portugal. Published in Diário de Notícias, Nov/Dec 2014.

António de Oliveira Salazar was the fascist dictator that ruled portugal from 1932 to 1968. Some historians "claim that his early reforms and policies allowed political and financial stability and therefore social order and economic growth, after the politically unstable and financially chaotic years of the Portuguese First Republic." Others "claim that Salazar's policies from the 1930s to the 1950s led to economic and social stagnation and rampant emigration, turning portugal into one of the poorest countries in Western Europe." -- from Wikipedia
